subj-group.subject: State-Local Finances After the Great Recession (State and Local)

title-group.article-title: Slow tax revenue growth, rising pension contributions, and Medicaid growth lead state and local governments to reshape their finances

abstract.p: This paper analyzes and describes major changes in state and local government finances since the Great Recession. Governments have been struggling with three major sources of fiscal stress: slow tax revenue growth; growth in pension contributions heavily concentrated in a few states; and Medicaid spending growth driven by recession-related enrollment. Conditions vary greatly across states but the combined effect has been substantial: between 2008 and 2015 real per capita state and local government pension contributions plus state-funded Medicaid grew by more than state and local government tax revenue in 31 states. In response, state and local governments have cut infrastructure investment, slashed support for higher education, cut social benefits other than Medicaid, cut spending on K-12 education, reduced administrative staff, and reduced most other areas of the budget. The paper concludes that many states will continue to struggle with these three pressures, at least in the near term.

caption.p: The recovery in state and local government tax revenue has been slow
State tax revenue adjusted for inflation and population growth is lower in 25 states than at the start of the recession
Inflation-adjusted pension contributions have gone up substantially, with wide variation across states
Inflation-adjusted state Medicaid spending is up $37 billion since 2008, driven by recession-related enrollment
Inflation-adjusted state-funded Medicaid spending per-capita was up in 45 states
Pension contributions and Medicaid combined grew by nearly as much as state & local government taxes between 2008 and 2015
Pension contributions plus state-funded Medicaid, combined, have grown by more than taxes in 31 states
State and local government inflation-adjusted expenditures increased by 0.3% between 2009 and 2015
State and local government net investment spending is lower, as a percentage of gross domestic product, than at any point in more than 50 years
Most categories of gross investment are down by double-digit percentages since 2009
Capital expenditures are down in 43 states
States and localities have cut spending on most “consumption” activities, adjusted for inflation
States are increasingly relying on tuition to finance higher education
States have been cutting spending on K-12 education
State and local government employment is down by more than half a million jobs
State and local government employment is lower than in 2009 in 35 states
States predict weak income and sales tax revenue growth in 2017
State personal income and sales tax revenue actual collections for FY 2015 and FY 2016 and forecasts for FY 2017
Economy, Employment, and Taxes in Oil- and Mineral-Dependent States
Pension underfunding is almost as great, as a percentage of GDP, as it was right after the severe market drops of the Great Recession
